Sure, here's a generic production deployment plan:

1. Divert all traffic to secondary data center, so no traffic in primary data center
2. Stop application(s) in the primary data center
3. Stop dependent services in the primary data center
4. Deploy dependent services in the primary data center
5. Deploy application(s) in the primary data center
6. Start dependent services in the primary data center
7. Start application(s) in the primary data center
8. Perform Private Verification Test (PVT) in the primary data center and sign off on it
9. Divert all traffic to primary data center, so no traffic in secondary data center
10. Stop application(s) in the secondary data center
11. Stop dependent services in the secondary data center
12. Deploy dependent services in the secondary data center
13. Deploy application(s) in the secondary data center
14. Start dependent services in the secondary data center
15. Start application(s) in the secondary data center
16. Perform PVT in the secondary data center and sign off on it
17. Switch to load balanced traffic
18. Monitor the system

This plan can be used for deploying any application or service that depends on other services. It's essential to have a clear deployment plan to minimize downtime and ensure a smooth transition. The plan involves rolling out changes in one data center at a time to ensure that the system remains operational while updates are made. The final step involves switching to load balanced traffic to ensure that the system can handle traffic from both data centers. It's crucial to monitor the system after deployment to ensure that everything is running smoothly and to quickly address any issues that arise.
